availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

Caption title: Trait√© entre le roy tres chretien, le roy de la Grande Bretagne, & les Seigneurs Estats Generaux des Provinces Unies de Pais bas : A treaty between the Most Christian King, the King of Great Britain, and the Lords States General of the United Provinces of the Low Countries.
French and English in parallel columns.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE following Treaty having for a con≈øiderable time been the Subject of the Gazettes beyond Sea, and of common Di≈øcour≈øe here, and an Ab≈øtract thereof having been publi≈øhed very Imperfect, if not Erroneous; for the Information of Mankind it is here tran≈ølated from the be≈øt Copy that could be gotten, to let the Nation ≈øee the care his Maje≈øty takes to prevent new VVars, and by con≈øequence the further Effu≈øion of our Blood and Trea≈øure.

THE TREATY BETWIXT The Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, The King of Great Britain, and The States General of the ∆≤nited Provinces, For ≈øettling the Succe≈ø≈øion of the Crown of Spain, and the Dominions thereunto belonging, in ca≈øe his Catholick Maje≈øty die without I≈ø≈øue.
LONDON; Printed for A. Baldwin in Warwick-lane. M. DCC.

div.head: Trait√© entre le Roy tres Chretien, le Roy de la Grande Bretagne, & les Seigneurs E≈øtats Generaux des Provinces Unies des Pais bas.
div.p:
SOIT notoire √† tous qui ces pre≈øentes verront, que le ≈øereni≈ø≈øime & tres pui≈ø≈øant prince Louis 14me par la grace de Dieu Roy tres Chre≈øtien de France & de Navarre, &c. & le ≈øereni≈ø≈øime & tres pui≈ø≈øant prince Guillaume 3me au≈øi par la grace de Dieu Roy de la grande Bretagne, & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats generaux des Provinces ∆≤nies des pais bas, n' ayant rien de plus a coeur que de fortifier par des nouvelles liai≈øons la bonne intelligence re≈øtablie entre ≈øa Maje≈øte tres Chret. ≈øa Maje≈øte de la grande Bret. & le≈ød. ≈øeigneurs Estats generaux par la dernier trait√© conclu √† Ri≈øwick, & de prevenir par me≈øures pri≈øes √† temps les evenements qui pourroient exciter de nouvelles guerres dans l' Europe; ont donn√© pour cet effet leurs pleins pouvoirs pour convenir d' un nouveau trait√© ≈øcavoir ≈øa dite Maje≈øte tres Chret. au Sieur Camille d' Hortung, Comte de Tallard, Lieut. general des
arme√©s du Roy & de la province de Dauphin√©, Amba≈ø≈øadeur extraordinaire de France en Angleterre; & au Sieur Gabriel Comte de Briord, Marquis de Senezan, Con≈ø. du Roy en ≈øes con≈øeils, & ≈øon Amba≈ø≈øadeur extraord. aupres de≈ød. ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux des Provinces v. des p. b. Sad. Ma. Brit. au Sieur Guillaume‚ñ™ Comte de Portlant, Vicomte de Cirence≈øter, Baron de Woodstock, Chevalier de l' ordre de la jarretiere, & Con≈ør. du Roy en ≈øon con≈øeil priv√©; & au Sieur Edward Comte de Jer≈øey, Vicomte de Villiers, Baron de How, Chevalier Marechal d' Angleterre, premier Secret‚ñ™ d' estat, & Con≈ør. du Roy en ≈øon con≈øeil priv√©; & le≈ød. ≈øeignieurs E≈øtats Gr√¢ux aux ≈øeignieurs Jean van Er≈øen bourguemaitre & ≈øenateur de la ville de Zutphen, Curateur de ∆≤niver≈øit√© a Harderwick; Frederick Baron de Rheede ≈øeigneur de Lier; St. Antoine Berle√© de l' ordre de la Noble≈ø≈øe a' Hollande & We≈øt Frize; Antoine Hein≈øius con≈ør. pen≈øionare, garde du grand ≈øceau, & ≈øurjntendant des fiefs de la meme province; Guillaume de Na≈ø≈øau ≈øeigneur de Odyeck Cortigene, & premier noble & repre≈øentant la noble≈ø≈øe dans l' a≈ø≈øemble√© des E≈øtats & de Deputes, Con≈ør. de Zelande; Everhard de Veede, ≈øeigneur de Weede, Dickvelt, Rateles, & ≈øeigneur foncier de la ville d' Oudewater,
doyen & e≈øcola≈øtre du chapitre Imperiale de St. Marie a ∆≤trecht, Diekgrave de la Riviere du Rhin dans la Province d' ∆≤trecht, & pre≈øident des e≈øtats de la meme province; Guillaume van Harein; Grietman du Bild deput√© de la Noble≈ø≈øe aux E≈øtats de Frize, & Curateur de l' univer≈øit√© de Franecker; Arnold Lemcker, Bourgomatre de Deventer; & Jean van Heeck, ≈øenateur de la ville de Gronningue, tous Deputes dans l' a≈ø≈øemblee de≈ødt. ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats generaux, de la part des E≈øtats de Gueldre, de Hollande & We≈øt Frize, de Zeelande, d'∆≤trecht, de Frize, d'Overi≈ø≈øel, & de Groningue & Omelandes; le≈øquels en vertu de≈øds. pouvoirs ≈øont convenus des articles ≈øuivans.

div.head: Article I.
div.p: La Paix re≈øtablie par le trait√© de Ri≈øwick entre ≈øa Maje≈øte tres Chretienne, ≈øa Maje≈øte Britanique, & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux des Provinces ∆≤nies des Pais Bas, leur heritiers & ≈øucce≈ø≈øeurs, leurs Royaumes, E≈øtats, & Sujets, ≈øera ferme & con≈øtante; & leurs Maje≈øtes, & le≈ødits ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Graux des P. ∆≤. des P. B. feront reciproquement tout ce qui pourra contribuer a l' avantage & a l' utilite de l' un & de l' autre.

div.head: II.
div.p: Comme le principal objet que ≈øad. Maje≈øte tres Chre≈ø. ≈øa dite Maje≈øte de la G. B. & lesd ≈øeigneurs E. G. ≈øe propo≈øent, e≈øt celuy de maintenir la tranquilite generale de l' Europe, ils n' ont p√º voir ≈øans douleur que l' estat de la ≈øante du Roy d' E≈øpagne ≈øoit depuis quelque tems devenu ≈øi langui≈ø≈øant, qu' il y a tout a craindre pour la vie de ce prince; quoy qu' ils ne pui≈ø≈øent tourner leurs pen≈øees du co≈øt√© de cet evenement ≈øans affliction par l' amitie ≈øincere & veritable qu' ils ont pour luy, ils ont cependant e≈øtim√© qu' il e≈øtoit d' autant plus nece≈ø≈øaire de le prevoir que ≈øa Maje≈øte Cathol. n' ayant point d' enfans, l' ouverture de la ≈øucce≈ø≈øion exciteroit infailliblement une nouvelle guerre ≈øile Roy tres Chret. ≈øoutenoit ≈øes preten≈øions, celles de Mon≈ø. le Dauphin ou de ≈øes de≈øcendans ≈øur toute la ≈øucce≈ø≈øion d' E≈øpagne, & que l' Empereur voulut au≈ø≈øy faire valoir ≈øes preten≈øions, celles du Roy des Romains de l' Archi-Duc ≈øon ≈øecond fils ou de ≈øes autres enfans ma≈øles ou femelles ≈øur lad. ≈øucce≈ø≈øion.

div.head: III.
div.p: Et Comme les deux ≈øeigneurs Roys & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux veulent ≈øur toutes cho≈øes la con≈øervation, du repos public & d' eviter une nouvelle guerre dans l' Europe pour un accommodement des di≈øputes & des differents qui pourroient re≈øulter au ≈øujet de lad. ≈øucce≈ø≈øion ou par l' ombrage de trois E≈øtats reunis ≈øous un me≈øme Prince, ils ont trouv√© bon de prendre par avance des me≈øures nece≈ø≈øaires pour prevenir les malheurs que le tri≈øte evenement de la mort du Roy Cathol. ≈øans Enfans pourroit produire.

div.head: IV.
div.p:
Ain≈øy √° et√© accorde & convenu que ≈øi le dit c√¢s arrivoit le Roy tres Chret. tant en ≈øon propee nom qu √©n celuy de Mon≈ø. le Dauph. ≈øes Enfans Ma≈øles ou Heritiers & Succe≈ø≈øeurs, nez & √° naitre; comme au≈ø≈øy Mon≈ø. le Dauph. pour ≈øoy meme, ≈øes Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. ≈øe tiendront ≈øatisfaits, comme ils ≈øe tiennent ≈øatisfaits par la pre≈øente, que Mon≈ø. le Dauphin ait pour ≈øon partage en toute propriete po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pleniere & extinction de toutes ≈øes preten≈øions ≈øur la ≈øucce≈ø≈øion de E≈øpagne, pour en jouir, luy, ≈øes Heritiers, Succe≈ø≈øeurs
de≈øcendans Ma≈øles ou &c. a perpetuit√© ≈øans pouvoir etre jamais troubl√© ≈øous quelque pretexte que ce ≈øoit de droits ou de preten≈øions directement on indirectement, mem√© par ce≈ø≈øions, appel, revolte, ou autre v√¥ye de la part de l' Empereur, du Roy des Romains du ≈øerereni≈øs, M. Archiduc Charles Son ≈øecond fils, des Archiduche≈ø≈øes, de ≈øes autres Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. les Roiaumes de Naples, & de Sicilie en la mannere que les E≈øpagnols les po≈ø≈øedent pre≈øentement, les places dependantes de la Monarchie d' E≈øpagne, ≈øituees ≈øur la cote de To≈øcane ou j≈øles adjacentes compri≈øes, ≈øous le nom de Sancto Stephano, Porto Hercole, Orbitello, Palamone, Portolongo, Piombin, en la maniere au≈ø≈øy que les E≈øpagnols les tiennent pre≈øentement, la ville & le Marqui≈øat de Final en la mani√©re pareillement que les tiennent, la Province de Guipu≈øcoa nommement les villes de Fontarabie, & de St. Seba≈øtien ≈øituees dans cette Province & ≈øpecialement le port du Pa≈ø≈øage qui e≈øt compris avec cette re≈øtriction ≈øeulement que≈ø‚ñ™ il y a quelques lieux dependans de lad. province qui ≈øe trouuent ≈øituez au de la de Pirennees ou autres Montagnes de Navarre d' Alava ou de Bi≈øcaye du co≈øte de l' E≈øpagne, ils re≈øteront √° l' E≈øpagne, & ≈ø'il y a quelques lieux pareillement dependans des provinces ≈øoumi≈øes √° l' E≈øpagne qui ≈øoient en
deca de Pirennees ou autres Montagnes qui ≈øe tr√≥uveront entre lad‚ñ™ province de Guipu≈øcoa Navarre Alava & de Bi≈øcaye √° qui qu' elles appartiennent ≈øeront partagees entre la France & l' l' E≈øpagne, en ≈øorte qu' il re≈øtera autant de≈ød. Montagnes & traje≈øts √° la France de ≈øon Co≈øte qu' il en re≈øtera a l'E≈øpagne du ≈øien, le tout avec les fortifications, munitions de guerre, poudres, boulets, canons, galleres, chiourmes, qui ≈øe trouveront appartenir au Roy d' E≈øpagne lors de ≈øon decez ≈øans Enfans & etre attachez aux Royaumes, Places, I≈øles & Provinces qui doivent compo≈øer le partage de Mon≈ø. le Dauphin bien entendu que les galleres, Chiourme & autres effects appartenant au Roy d' E≈øpagne par le Royaume d' E≈øpagne & autres E≈øtats qui tombent dans le partage du ≈øereni≈ø. Archd. luy resteront, celles qui appartiennent aux Royaumes de Naples & de Sicilie devant revenir √° Mon≈ø. le Dauphin ain≈øy qu' ily √° ete dit cy de≈ø≈øus.

De plus les E≈øtats de Mon≈ø. le Duc de Lorraine √¢ ≈øcavoir les Duches de Lorraine & de Bar ain≈øy que le Duc Charles W. du nom les po≈ø≈øedoit et tels qu' ils ont ete rendus par le Traite de Ri≈øwick ≈øeront cedez & tran≈øportez a Mon≈ø. le Dauphin ≈øes Enfans Heritiers & Succe≈ø≈øeurs Ma≈øles ou &c. en toute propriete & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pleniere a la place du Duch√©
de Milan qui ≈øera ced√© & tran≈øport√© en e≈øchange aud. Duc de Lorraine ≈øes Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. en toute propriet√© & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pleniere, lequel ne refu≈øera point un parti ≈øi avantageux, bien entendu que le Comt√© de Bitch appartient a Mon≈ø. le Prince de Vaudemont, lequel rentrera dans la po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion de terre dont ill a joui cy devant qui luy ont et√© ou doivent etre rendues en execution du Trait√© de Ri≈øwick, moy ennant le≈øquels Royaumes, I≈øles, Provinces & Places le≈ød. Roi tres Chret. tant en ≈øon propre nom qu' en celuy de Mon≈øeig. le Dauphin, ≈øes Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. lequel a au≈ø≈øy donn√© ≈øon pleinpouvoir au Sieur Comte de Tallard, & au Sieur Comte de Briord promettent & l' engagent de renoncer lors de l' ouverture de lad. Succe≈ø≈øion d' E≈øpagne comme en ce cas la ils renoncent des √° pre≈øent par celle cy √° tous ≈øes droits & preten≈øions ≈øur lad. couronne d' E≈øpagne & ≈øur tous les autres Royaumes, I≈øles, E≈øtats, pais & places qui en dependent pre≈øentement √° l' exception de ce qui e≈øt enonc√© cy de≈ø≈øus pour ≈øon partage, & de tout cela ils feront expedier des actes ≈øolemnels dans la plus forte, & la meilleure forme qu'il ≈øe pourra qui ≈øeront delivrez au temps de l' e≈øchange des ratiffications de ce pre≈øent Trait√© au Roy de la Grande Bretagne, & aux Seigneurs E≈øtats Generaux.

div.head: V.
div.p: Toutes les villes places & ports ≈øituez dans les Royaumes & provinces qui doivent compo≈øer le partage dud. Seig. Dauphin ≈øeront con≈øervez ≈øans etre demolis.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
La dite couronne d' E≈øpagne & les autres Royaumes I≈øles, E≈øtats, pais & places que le Roy Cathol. po≈ø≈øede pre≈øentement tant dehors que dedans l' Europe ≈øeront donnez & a≈ø≈øignez au ≈øeren. Archid. Charles 2d fils de l' Empereur √° l' exception de ce qui √° √©te donn√© dans l' Art. 4. qui doit compo≈øer le partage de Mon≈øeigneur le Dauphin, & du Duch√© de Milan en conformite uddit. Art. 4. en toute propriete & po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion pleniere en partage & extinction de toutes ≈øes preten≈øions ≈øur ladit. Succe≈ø≈øion d' E≈øpagne pour en jouir, luy ≈øes Heritiers, & Succe≈ø≈øeurs nez & √° naitre a perpetuit√© ≈øans pouvoir √©tre jamais troubl√© ≈øous quelque pretexte que ce ≈øoit de droits ou des preten≈øions directement ny indirectement, meme par ce≈ø≈øion, appel, revolte ou autre voye de la part du Roy tres Chret. de Mon≈øegnieur le Dauphin ou de ≈øes Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. moyennant laquelle la Couronne de'E≈øpagne &
les autres Royaumes, I≈øles, E≈øtats, pais & places qui en dependent, l' Empeeur tant en ≈øon propre nom qu' en celuy du Roy des Romains, du ≈øeren. Archd. Charl. ≈øon. 2d fils, des Archiduche≈ø≈øes ≈øes filles, ≈øes Enfans leurs Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. comme au≈ø≈øy le Roy des Rom. pour luy & le ≈øeren. Archd. Char. des qu' il ≈øera majeur pour luy meme leurs Enfans &c. ≈øe tiendront ≈øatisfaits que led. ≈øeren. Archd. Char. ait en extinction de toutes leurs preten≈øions ≈øur la ≈øucce≈ø≈øion de E≈øpagne, la dit Ce≈ø≈øion faite cy de≈ø≈øus, & led. Empereur tanen ≈øon propre nom qu' en celuy du Roy des Rom. du ≈øeren. Archd. Char. ≈øon. 2d Fils, des Archiduche≈ø≈øes ≈øes filles, ≈øes Enfans Ma≈øles ou &c. ou les leurs, comme au≈ø≈øy led. Roy des Rom. en ≈øon propre nom renonceront lors qu'ils entreront en ce pre≈øent Trait√© & qu' ils le ratiffieront & le ≈øeren. Archd. Char. des qu' il ≈øera majeur, a tous autres droits & preten≈øions ≈øur les Royaumes, I≈øles, E≈øtats, pais & places qui compo≈øent les partages, & les portions a≈ø≈øignez cy de≈ø≈øus √° Mon≈øeigneur le Dauphin de celuy qui aura le Duch√© de Milan par e≈øchange de ce qui ≈øera donn√© √° Mon≈øeigneur le Dauphin & que de tout cela ils feront expedier des actes ≈øolemnels dans la plus forte & la meilleure forme qu' il ≈øe pourra, ≈øcavoir l' Empereur & le
Roy des Rom. quand. ils ratifieront ce pre≈øent trait√©, & le ≈øereni≈ø≈øime Archi-Duc des qu'il ≈øera Majeur, les quels ≈øeront delivrez a ≈øa Maje≈øte Brit. & aux ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux.

div.head: VII.
div.p:
Immediatement apres l' e≈øchange des ratifications de ce pre≈øent trait√© il ≈øera communiqu√© √† l' Empereur lequel ≈øera invit√© d' y entrer; mais ≈øi trois mois apres √† compter du jour de la dite communication, & de lad. invitation, ou le jour que ≈øa maje≈øte Cathol. viendroit a mourir, ≈øi c√© toit avant led. terme de trois mois ≈øa Maje≈øte Imp. & le Roy du Rom refu≈øoient d' y entrer & de convenir du partage a≈ø≈øign√© au ≈øereni≈ø≈øime Arch-d. les deux ≈øeigneurs Roys ou leurs ≈øucce≈ø≈øeurs, & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux conviendront d' un prince auquel led. partage ≈øera donn√©, & en cas que non ob≈øtant la pre≈øente convention led ≈øereni≈ø≈øime Archi-Duc voulut prendre po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ou de la portion qui luy ≈øera eche√ºe avant qu' il eut accept√© le pre≈øent trait√©, ou de celle qui ≈øeroit a≈ø≈øign√® √† Mon≈øeigneur le Dauph. ou
√† celuy qui aura le Duch√© de Milan par exchange comme il e≈øt dit cy de≈ø≈øus, le≈ød. Deux ≈øeigneurs Roys & les ≈øeignieurs E≈øtats Generaux en vertu de cette convention l' empecheront de toutes leurs forces.

div.head: VIII.
div.p: Le ≈øereni≈ø≈øime l' Archi-Duc ne pourra pa≈ø≈øer en E≈øpagne ny dans le Duch√© de Milan du vivant de ≈øa Maje≈øt√© Cathol. que d' un commun con≈øentement, & point autrement.

div.head: IX.
div.p:
Si le Sereni≈ø≈øime Archi-Duc vient √† mourir ≈øans Enfans, ≈øoit avant on aprez la mort du Roy Cath. le partage qui luy e≈øt a≈ø≈øign√© cy de≈ø≈øus par l' art. de ce trait√© pa≈ø≈øera √† tel enfant de l' Empereur ma≈øle ou, &c. hors le Roy des Rom. ou tel enfans ma≈øles ou, &c. du Roy des Rom. que ≈øa Maje≈øte Imple trouvera bon de de≈øigner, & en cas que ≈øad. Majeste Imple vient a deceder ≈øans avoir fait la ≈øupd. de≈øignation elle pourra etre faite par le Roy des Rom. mais le tout a condition que led. partage ne pourra jamais etre reuni ny demeurer en la per≈øonne de celuy qui ≈øera Empereur ou Roy de Rom.
ou qu' qui ≈øera devenu l' un ou l' autre ≈øoit par ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, te≈øtament, contrait de marriage, donation, e≈øchange, ce≈ø≈øion, appel, revolte, ou autre voye‚ñ™ & de meme led. partage du ≈øereni≈ø≈øime Arch-Duc, ne pourra jamais revenir ny demeurer en la per≈øonne d' un prince qui ≈øera Roy de France ou Dauphin, ou qui ≈øera devenu l' un ou l' autre, ≈øoit par ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, te≈øtament, contract de mariage, donation, &c.

div.head: X.
div.p:
Le Roy d' E≈øpagne venant a mourir ≈øans enfans & ain≈øy le ≈øu≈ød. cas arrivant, les deux ≈øeigneurs Rois & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux s' obligent de lai≈ø≈øer toute la ≈øucce≈ø≈øion dans l' etat comme alors elle ≈øe trouvera ≈øans s' en ≈øai≈øir en tout ou en partie directement ou indirectement, mais chaque prince pourra d' alors ≈øe mettre en po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion de ce qui luy e≈øt a≈ø≈øign√© pour ≈øon partage, des qu' il aura ≈øatisfait de ≈øa part aux art. 4 & 6 precedens celuy cy; & s' il y trouve de la difficult√©, les deux ≈øeigneurs
Rois & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats generaux feront tous leurs devoirs po≈ø≈øibles afin que chacun ≈øoit mis en po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion de ≈øa portion ≈øelon cette convention, & qu' elle pui≈ø≈øe avoir ≈øon entier effet, s' engageant √† donner par mer & par terre les ≈øecours & a≈ø≈øi≈øtances d' hommes & de vai≈ø≈øeaux nece≈ø≈øaires pour contraindre par la force ceux qui s' oppo≈øeront a ladit‚ñ™ execution.

div.head: XI.
div.p: Si le≈ød. ≈øeigneurs Roys & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux on quelq un d' eux ≈øont attaquez de qui que ce ≈øoit a cau≈øe de cette convention, ou de l' execution qu' on en fera, on s' a≈ø≈øi≈øtera mutuellement l' un l' autre avec toutes ≈øes forces, & on ≈øe rendra garand de la ponctuelle execution de le≈ød. convention, & des renonciations faites en con≈øequence.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
Seront admis dans le pre≈øent trait√© tous Rois, Princes, E≈øtats qui voudront y entrer, & il ≈øera permis aux deux ≈øeigneurs Rois & aux ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux
& √† chachun d' eux en particulier de requerir et inviter tous ceux qu' ils trouveront bon de requerir & inviter d' entrer dans ce pre≈øent trait√© & d' etre ≈øemblablement garands de l' execution de ce trait√© & de la validite des renontiations qui y ≈øont contenues.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
Et pour a≈ø≈øurer encore d' avantage le repos de l' Europe, le≈ød. Rois, Princes & E≈øtats ≈øeront non ≈øeulment invitez d' etre garands de lad. execution du pre≈øent trait√© & de la validite de≈ød. renonciations comme cy de≈ø≈øus: mais ≈øi quelqu' un' des princes en faveur de≈øquels les partages ≈øont faits, vouloit dans la ≈øuite troubler l' ordre √©tabli par ce trait√©, faire des nouvelles entrepri≈øes y contraires & ain≈øy s' aggrandir aux depens les uns des autres ≈øous quelque pretexte que ce ≈øoit, la meme garantie du trait√© ≈øera cen≈øe√© devoir s' e≈øtender au≈ø≈øy en ce cas, en ≈øorte que les Rois, Princes & E≈øtats qui promettent ≈øeront tenus d' employer leurs forces pour s' oppo≈øer auxd. entrepri≈øes & pour maintenir
toutes cho≈øes dans l' etat convenu par le≈ød‚ñ™ articles.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: Que ≈øi quelque Prince qui ce ≈øoit s' oppo≈øe a la pri≈øe de po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion des partages convenus le≈ød. deux ≈øeigneurs Rois & les ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux ≈øeront obliges de s' entr' aider l' un l' autre contre cette oppo≈øition & de l' empecher avec toutes leurs forces, & l' on conveniendra d' abord apres la ≈øignatur√© du pre≈øent trait√© de la proportion que chacun doit contribuer tant par mer que par terre.

div.head: XV.
div.p:
Le pre≈øent trait√© & tous les actes faits en con≈øequence ou qui y ont rapport & nommement les actes ≈øolemnels que ≈øa Maje≈øte tres Chret. & Mon≈øeigneur le Dauphin ≈øont obliges de donner en vertu de l' art 4. cy de≈ø≈øus ≈øeront enregi≈øtrez au parlement de Paris ≈øuivant le forme & teneur & l' u≈øage ordinaire pour avoir lieu aux conditions qui y ≈øont
porte√©s des que l' Empereur ≈øera entr√© dans le pre≈øent trait√© ou au bout de trois mois qui luy ≈øont donnez pour cet effet s' il ny entre pas plus tot, & pareillement ≈øa Maje≈øte Imperiale ≈øera ten√ºe quand elle entrera dans le pre≈øent trait√© de le faire approuver & enregi≈øtrer avec tous les actes faits en con≈øequence, ou qui y ont rapport, nommement les actes ≈øolemnels que ≈ø. Maje≈øte Imperiale le Roy des Rom. & le ≈øereni≈ø≈øime Archi-Duc ≈øeront obligez de donner en vertu de l' art. 6 cy de≈ø≈øus en con≈øeil d' Etat ou ailleurs ≈øuivant les formes les plus authentiques du pais.

div.head: XVI.
div.p:
Les ratifications des deux ≈øeigneurs Rois & des ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux ≈øeront toutes trois e≈øchange√©s en meme tems √° Londres dans l' e≈øpace de trois ≈øemaines, a compter du jour que le≈ød. ≈øeigneurs E≈øtat. Generaux auront ≈øign√© ou pl√∫tot ≈øi faire ≈øe peut. Fait & ≈øign√© √° Londres le 3 Mars N. S. 1700. 21 Feb. V. S. 1699. par nous plenipotentiares de France & Angleterre, & √† la Haye le 25. ded.
mois de Mars 1700. & par nous plenipotentiares de France & des ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux les deux ≈øeigneurs Rois & le≈ød. ≈øeigneurs E≈øtats Generaux etant convenus que la ≈øignature de le pre≈øent trait√© ≈øe feroit de la ≈øorte, en foy de quoy nous avons ≈øign√© led. pre≈øent trait√© de notre main & fait appo≈øer le cachet de nos armes.

closer.signed: Signe Tallard, Briord, Portland, Jer≈øey, J. van Er≈øen, F. B. de Reede, & Hein≈øius, W. de Na≈ø≈øau, E. de Weede, W. van Haren, Ar. Lemker, van Heek, avec leurs cachetes.

div.head: A TREATY between the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, the King of Great Britain, and the Lords States General of the United Provinces of the Low Countries.
div.p:
BE it known to all who ≈øhall ≈øee the≈øe pre≈øents, That the mo≈øt ≈øerene and mo≈øt potent Prince Lewis XIV. by the Grace of God mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of France and Navarre, &c. and the mo≈øt ≈øerene and mo≈øt potent Prince William III. al≈øo by the Grace of God King of Great Britain, &c. and the Lords States General of the United Provinces of the Low Countries, having nothing more in de≈øign than to confirm by new Obligations that good Intelligence ree≈øtabli≈øh'd between his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, his Maje≈øty of Great Britain, and the ≈øaid Lords States General of the United Provinces by the la≈øt Treaty concluded at Re≈øwick; and to prevent, by taking timely Mea≈øures, tho≈øe Events which may rai≈øe new Wars in Europe; Have to this end given their full Powers to conclude a new Treaty: that is to ≈øay, his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty to the Sieur Camille d' Hortung, Count de Tallard Lieutenant‚ñ™
General of the King's Armies, and of his Province of Dauphiny, Amba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary of France in England; and to the Sieur Gabriel Count de Briord, Marqui≈øs de Senezan, one of his Maje≈øty's Privy Council, and his Amba≈ø≈øador Extraordinary to the States General of the United Provinces of the Low Countries: his ≈øaid Britannick Maje≈øty to the Sieur William Earl of Portland, Vi≈øcount of Cirence≈øter, Baron of Wood≈øtock, Knight of the Garter, and Privy Coun≈øellor to the King; and to the Sieur Edward Earl of Jer≈øy, Vi≈øcount Villars, Baron of How, Knight Mar≈øhal of England, fir≈øt Secretary of State, and Privy Coun≈øellor to the King: and the ≈øaid States General to the Lords John van Er≈øen, Burgoma≈øter and Senator of the Town of Zutphen, Curator of the Univer≈øity of Harderwye ‚Ä¢ k; Frederick Baron Rheede, Lord de Lier; St. Anthony Berlee, of the Order of the Nobility of Holland and We≈øt Frizeland; Anthony Hen≈øius, Coun≈øellor, Pen≈øionary, Keeper of the Great Seal, and Superintendant of the Fiefs of the ≈øame Province; William of Na≈ø≈øau, Lord d'Odyke Cortigene, fir≈øt Noble and Repre≈øentative of the Nobility in the A≈ø≈øembly of the States and of the Deputies, Coun≈øellor of Zealand; Everhard de Veede, Ld of Weede, Dickvelt, Ratteles, Ld of the Mannor of the
Town of Oudewater, Dean and Member of the Imperial Chapter of St. Mary of ∆≤trecht, Dickgrave of the River Rhine in the Province of ∆≤trecht and Pre≈øident of the States of the ≈øame Province; William van Harein; Grietman du Bild, Deputy of the Nobility of the States of Friezland, Procurator of the Univer≈øity of Franeker; Arnold Lemsker, Burgoma≈øter of Deventer; and John van Heek, Senator of the Town of Groningen; all Deputies of the ≈øaid Lords States General, on behalf of Guelderland, Holland, and We≈øt Friezland, of Zealand, of ∆≤trecht, of Friezland, of Overy≈øel, and of Groningen and Omelandt: who by virtue of the ≈øaid Powers have agreed to the following Articles.

div.head: Article I.
div.p: The Peace ree≈øtabli≈øht by the Treaty of Re≈øwick between his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, his Britannick Maje≈øty, and Lords States General of the United Provinces of the Low Countries, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, their Kingdoms, States and Subjects, ≈øhall be firm and con≈øtant; and their Maje≈øties, and the ≈øaid Lords States General of the United Provinces of the Low Countries, ≈øhall reciprocally do what they can to contribute to the advantage and profit of one another.

div.head: II.
div.p: As the principal object which his ≈øaid mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty, his ≈øaid Maje≈øty of Great Britain, and the ≈øaid States General propo≈øe to them≈øelves, is, that of maintaining the general Tranquillity of Europe, they could not without ≈øorrow under≈øtand that the ≈øtate of the King of Spain's Health hath for ≈øome time been ≈øo langui≈øhing, that the Life of the ≈øaid Prince is much feared: tho they cannot think upon this Event without trouble, becau≈øe of the ≈øincere and true Love they have for him, they have neverthele≈øs thought it the more nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øider it, becau≈øe his Catholick Maje≈øty having no Children, the bu≈øine≈øs of the Succe≈ø≈øion will infallibly rai≈øe a new War, if the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King ≈øhould maintain his own Preten≈øions, tho≈øe of Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, or of his Succe≈ø≈øors, to the whole Succe≈ø≈øion of Spain; and if the Emperor ≈øhould al≈øo make good his Preten≈øions, tho≈øe of the King of the Romans, of the Arch-Duke his ≈øecond Son, or of his other Children, Males or Females, unto the ≈øaid Succe≈ø≈øion.

div.head: III.
div.p: And as the two Kings, and the Lords the States General, de≈øire above all things the Con≈øervation of the publick Peace, and to prevent a new War in Europe, by accommodating the Di≈øputes and Differences, which might ari≈øe upon the Subject of the ≈øaid Succe≈ø≈øion, or by the Umbrage of three E≈øtates reunited under one and the ≈øame Prince, they have thought good to take beforehand nece≈ø≈øary mea≈øures to prevent the Evils which the ≈øorrowful Event of the Catholick King's Death without Children might produce.

div.head: IV.
div.p:
Therefore it is agreed, that if it ≈øhould ≈øo happen, the Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, as well in his own Name, as in that of Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, his Male Children, Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, born or to be born; as al≈øo Mon≈ø. the Dauphin for him≈øelf, his Male Children, &c. ≈øhall hold him≈øelf ≈øatisfy'd, and do hold them≈øelves ≈øatisfy'd by the≈øe Pre≈øents, That Mon≈øeig. the Dauphin ≈øhall have for his Share in full Property and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and in lieu of all his Preten≈øions to the Succe≈ø≈øion of Spain, to be enjoy'd by him, his Heirs,
Succe≈ø≈øors, De≈øcendants, Males, or, &c. for ever, without ever being mole≈øted under any pretence what≈øoever in his Rights or Preten≈øions, directly or indirectly, either by Ce≈ø≈øion, Appeal, Revolt, or otherways, by the Emperor, the King of the Romans, the mo≈øt Serene Archduke Charles his Second Son, the Arch-Dutche≈øs, his other I≈ø≈øue Male, or, &c. the Kingdoms of Naples and of Sicily in the ≈øame manner the Spaniards po≈ø≈øe≈øs them at pre≈øent, the Places depending upon the Monarchy of Spain, ≈øituated on the Coa≈øt of Tu≈øcany, or the I≈øles adjacent, being therein comprehended, under the name of Sancto Stephano, Porto Hercole, Orbitello, Palamone, Portolongo, Piombin. In that ≈øame manner al≈øo as the Spaniards po≈ø≈øe≈øs them at pre≈øent, the City and Marqui≈øate of Final; in that ≈øame manner al≈øo as they po≈ø≈øe≈øs them, the Province of Guipu≈øcoa, and particularly the Cities of Fontarabia and St. Seba≈øtian ≈øituated in that Province, and e≈øpecially the Port of Pa≈ø≈øage which is therein comprehended, with this Re≈øtriction only, that if there be any places depending‚ñ™ upon the ≈øaid Province, which ≈øhall be found ≈øituated beyond the Pyrenees, or the other Mountains of Navarr, Alava, or Bi≈øcay, on the ≈øide of Spain, they ≈øhall remain to Spain; and if there be
any places in like manner depending upon the Provinces ≈øubjected to Spain, which are on this ≈øide the Pyrenees, or other Mountains betwixt the ≈øaid Province of Guipu≈øcoa, Navarr, Alava and Bi≈øcay, let them belong to whom they will, they ≈øhall be divided between France and Spain, in ≈øuch ≈øort as there ≈øhall remain as much of the ≈øaid Mountains and Pa≈ø≈øes to France on her ≈øide, as ≈øhall remain to Spain on hers; the whole with the Fortifications, Ammunition of War, Powder, Ball, Cannon, Gallies, Gally≈ølaves, which ≈øhall be found belonging to the K. of Spain at the time of his Decea≈øe without I≈ø≈øue, and to be annext to the Kingdoms, Places, I≈ølands and Provinces which are to compo≈øe the ≈øhare of Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, provided that the Gallies, the Gally≈ølaves, and the Effects, belonging to the K. of Spain for the Kingdom of Spain, and other Dominions, which fall to the ≈øhare of the mo≈øt Serene Archduke, ≈øhall remain to him; tho≈øe which belong to the Kingdoms of Naples and Sicily being to return to Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin ≈øo as above≈øaid.

Further, the Dominions of the Duke of Lorrain, that is to ≈øay the Dutchies of Lorrain and Bar, ≈øo as Charles IV. of that name po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd them, and as they were re≈øtor'd by the Treaty of Re≈øwyk, ≈øhall be yielded
and transferr'd to Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors Males, or, &c. in Property and full Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in lieu of the Dutchy of Milan, which ≈øhall be quitted and exchanged to the ≈øaid D. of Lorrain, his Male Children, or, &c. in all Property, and full Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, who will not refu≈øe ≈øo advantagious a Bargain, it being under≈øtood that the County of Bitch belongs to Mon≈øieur the Prince of Vaudemont, who ≈øhall enter into Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lands which he heretofore enjoy'd, which have been, or ought to have been re≈øtor'd according to the Treaty of Re≈øwyck; on the account of which ≈øaid Kingdoms, I≈ølands, Provinces, and Places, the ≈øaid Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King as well in his own as in the name of Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, his Male Children, or, &c. who hath al≈øo given his full Power to the Count de Tallard, and to the Count de Briord, promi≈øing and engaging them≈øelves to renounce at the opening of the ≈øaid Succe≈ø≈øion of Spain, as in this ca≈øe, they have at this time renounced by the≈øe Pre≈øents all their Rights and Preten≈øions to the ≈øaid Crown of Spain, and to all the other Kingdoms, I≈ølands, States, Lands, and Places, which at this time depend thereupon, except what is above≈øaid excepted for his part; all which they ≈øhall confirm by ≈øolemn Acts in the
mo≈øt authentick and be≈øt form as may be; which ≈øhall be delivered at the time of the Exchange of the Ratification of this pre≈øent Treaty to the King of Great Britain, and the States General.

div.head: V.
div.p: All the Towns, Places, and Ports ≈øituate in the Kingdoms and Provinces which are to compo≈øe the ≈øhare of Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, ≈øhall be pre≈øerv'd without being demoli≈øh'd.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
The ≈øaid Crown of Spain and the other Kingdoms, I≈ølands, States, Lands and Places, which the Catholick King at this time po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes, as well within as without Europe, ≈øhall be given to the mo≈øt Serene Archduke Charles, Second Son to the Emperor, except what has been given in the 4th Art. for the ≈øhare of the Dauphin and of the Dutchy of Milan, according to the ≈øaid 4th Art. in full Propriety and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion as his part; excluding all his other Preten≈øions to the ≈øaid Succe≈ø≈øion of Spain, to enjoy the ≈øame for him≈øelf and Succe≈ø≈øors born or to be born for ever, without being ever mole≈øted under any Pretext what≈øoever of Rights or Preten≈øions
directly or indirectly, by Ce≈ø≈øion, Appeal, Revolt, or otherwi≈øe, on the part of the Mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King, or Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, or his Children Male, or, &c. for which ≈øaid Crown of Spain, and other Kingdoms, I≈ølands, and Places thereupon depending, the Emperor as well in his own Name, as in that of the King of the Romans, and the Archduke Charles his Second Son, the Archdutche≈ø≈øes his Daughters, his Children Males, or, &c. as al≈øo the King of the Romans for him≈øelf, and the mo≈øt Serene Archduke Charles, as ≈øoon as he ≈øhall be of Age, for him≈øelf, their Children, &c. ≈øhall be ≈øati≈øfy'd that the mo≈øt Serene Archduke Charles ≈øhall have in lieu of all their Preten≈øions upon the Crown of Spain, the ≈øaid Ce≈ø≈øion above≈øaid; and the ≈øaid Emperour as well in his own Name, as in that of the King of the Romans, the mo≈øt Serene Archduke Charles his Second Son, the Arch-Dutche≈ø≈øes his Daughters, his Children Males, or, &c. or their I≈ø≈øue. As al≈øo the ≈øaid King of the Romans in his own Name ≈øhall renounce, when they ≈øhall enter into, and ratify this pre≈øent Treaty, and the mo≈øt Serene Archduke Charles as ≈øoon as he ≈øhall be of Age, all other Rights and Preten≈øions to the ≈øaid Kingdoms, I≈ølands, States, Lands and Places
which compo≈øe the Share or Portion a≈ø≈øigned to Mon≈ø. Dauphin, and of him who ≈øhall have the Dutchy of Milan by exchange of what ≈øhall be given to Mon≈ø. the Dauphin, of all which they ≈øhall cau≈øe the mo≈øt ≈øolemn and authentick Acts to be made that may be; that is to ≈øay, the Emperor and the King of the Romans when they ≈øhall ratify this pre≈øent Treaty, and the mo≈øt ≈øerene Arch-Duke as ≈øoon as he ≈øhall come of age; which ≈øhall be deliver'd to his Brittanick Maje≈øty and the ≈øaid States General.

div.head: VII.
div.p:
Immediately after the Exchange and Ratification of this pre≈øent Treaty, it ≈øhall be communicated to the Emperor, who ≈øhall be invited to enter thereinto; but if, after three months time from the day of the ≈øaid Communication and the ≈øaid Invitation, or the day that his Catholick Maje≈øty ≈øhall die, if it happen before the expiration of the ≈øaid three months, his Imperial Maje≈øty and the King of the Romans ≈øhould refu≈øe to enter thereinto, and to agree to the ≈øhare a≈ø≈øigned to the mo≈øt ≈øerene Arch Duke Charles; the two Kings, or their Succe≈ø≈øors, and the States General ≈øhall agree upon a Prince to whom that part ≈øhall be given: and in ca≈øe, notwith≈øtanding the pre≈øent Convention, the mo≈øt ≈øerene Arch Duke ≈øhall take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion either of the part which might fall to him, before he has accepted
the pre≈øent Treaty, or of that part which might be a≈ø≈øign'd to Mon≈ø. Dauphin, or to him, who ≈øhall have the Dutchy of Milan in exchange, as above≈øaid, the ≈øaid two Kings and the States General, by virtue of this Convention, ≈øhall hinder him with all their Forces.

div.head: VIII.
div.p: The mo≈øt ≈øerene Arch Duke ≈øhall not pa≈øs into Spain, nor into the Dutchy of Milan, during the Life of his Catholick Maje≈øty, but with common con≈øent, and not otherwi≈øe.

div.head: IX.
div.p:
If the mo≈øt ≈øerene Arch-Duke ≈øhould dy without Children, either before or after the Death of the Catholick King, the ≈øhare which is hereby a≈ø≈øigned to him by the Articles of this Treaty, ≈øhall come to ≈øuch Male Child of the Emperor, or, &c. except the K. of the Romans, or ≈øuch Children, Males or, &c. of the K. of the Romans, which his Imperial Maje≈øty ≈øhall think fit to a≈ø≈øign it to: And in ca≈øe his ≈øaid Imperial Maje≈øty ≈øhould die without having made the above≈øaid A≈ø≈øignment, it may be done by the K. of the Romans; but on condition that the ≈øaid part ≈øhall never be united
nor belong to the per≈øon of him who ≈øhall be Emperor or King of the Romans, or is become one or the other, be it by Succe≈ø≈øion, Will, Contract of Marriage, Donation, Exchange, Ce≈ø≈øion, Appeal, Revolt, or otherways: And in like manner the ≈øaid ≈øhare of the ≈øerene Arch-Duke, ≈øhall never come or belong to the per≈øon of a Prince that ≈øhall be King or Dauphin of France, or that is become one or the other, be it by Succe≈ø≈øion, Will, Contract of Marriage, Donation, or otherwi≈øe.

div.head: X.
div.p:
The King of Spain dying without Children, &c. the above≈øaid Ca≈øe happening, the two Kings, and the States General, do oblige them≈øelves to leave the whole Succe≈ø≈øion in the ≈øame ≈øtate as it ≈øhall then be, without ≈øeizing the whole or any part directly or indirectly; but each Prince immediately may put him≈øelf in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of what is a≈ø≈øigned him as his ≈øhare, as ≈øoon as he has fulfill'd on his part the 4th and 6th preceding Articles; and in ca≈øe of difficulty, the two Kings, and the
States General ≈øhall do their utmo≈øt endeavours, to the end that each one ≈øhall be put in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈ø≈øion of his part according to this Agreement; and that it may have its entire effect, engage them≈øelves to give by Sea and Land ≈øuch help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Men and Ships as ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary to con≈øtrain by force ≈øuch who ≈øhall oppo≈øe the ≈øaid Execution.

div.head: XI.
div.p: If the above≈øaid Kings and States General, or either of them be attack'd becau≈øe of this Convention, or of the execution that ≈øhall be thereof made, they ≈øhall mutually a≈ø≈øi≈øt one another with all their Forces, and render them≈øelves Guarantees of the above≈øaid Convention, and of the Renunciations made thereupon.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
All Kings, Princes, and States, that will enter into the ≈øame, ≈øhall be admitted into the pre≈øent Treaty: and it ≈øhall be lawful to the two Kings, and States General,
and to each of them in particular, to require and invite all that they ≈øhall think fit, to enter into this pre≈øent Treaty, and to be jointly Guarantees for the execution thereof, and of the validity of the Renunciations herein contained.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
And for the further ≈øecuring the Peace of Europe, the ≈øaid Kings, Princes and States ≈øhall not only be invited to be Guarantees of the execution of the pre≈øent Treaty, and of the validity of the Renounciations, as above, but if any one of the Princes, in favour of whom the ≈øhares are a≈ø≈øigned, do in time to come break the Order e≈øtabli≈øh'd by this Treaty, and begin new Enterpri≈øes contrary to the ≈øame, and ≈øo aggrandize him≈øelf at the expence of one or other, under any pretence what≈øoever; the Guarranty of this Treaty ≈øhall be under≈øtood to extend ≈øo far al≈øo in this ca≈øe, that all the Kings, Princes and States who promi≈øe the ≈øame, ≈øhall be oblig'd to imploy their Forces again≈øt ≈øuch Enterpri≈øes, for the maintaining
all things in the ≈øame condition as agreed to by the ≈øaid Articles.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: In ca≈øe any Prince who≈øoever oppo≈øe the taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Shares agreed on, the ≈øaid two Kings, and the States, ≈øhall be obliged to a≈ø≈øi≈øt one another again≈øt ≈øuch oppo≈øition, and to hinder it with all their Forces, and ≈øhall agree after the ≈øigning of this pre≈øent Treaty, on the proportion that each ≈øhall contribute both by Sea and Land.

div.head: XV.
div.p:
The pre≈øent Treaty, and all Acts made, or that have dependance thereupon, and e≈øpecially the ≈øolemn Acts that his mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Maje≈øty and Mon≈øeigneur the Dauphin, are obliged to give by virtue of the 4th Article above≈øaid, ≈øhall be regi≈øtred in the Parliament of Paris, according to the Form and Tenure and u≈øual Cu≈øtom, to have place among≈øt the Conditions therein contained, as
≈øoon as the Emperor has entred into the pre≈øent Treaty, or at the end of 3 Months that are allowed him for that purpo≈øe, in ca≈øe he does not enter into it ≈øooner: and likewi≈øe his Imperial Maje≈øty, when he enters into the ≈øame, ≈øhall be obliged to get it approved and regi≈øtred, with all the Acts made in con≈øequence thereof, or which have relation thereunto; e≈øpecially the ≈øolemn Acts which his Imperial Maje≈øty, the King of the Romans, and the mo≈øt ≈øerene Arch-Duke ≈øhall be oblig'd to give, by virtue of the 6th Article above≈øaid, in the Council of State or otherwi≈øe, according to the mo≈øt authentick Form of the Country.

div.head: XVI.
div.p:
The Ratifications of the two Kings and the States General ≈øhall be all three exchang'd at London at the ≈øame time, within the ≈øpace of three Weeks, reckoning from the day that the States General ≈øhall have ≈øigned, or ≈øooner, if po≈ø≈øible. Done and ≈øigned at London, 3 March N. S. 1700. 21 Feb. V. S. 1699. by us Plenipotentiaries of France and England; and at the Hague, the 25th of the ≈øaid
Month of March, 1700. by us Plenipotentiaries of France, and of the States General, the two Kings and the ≈øaid States General having agreed that the ≈øigning of this pre≈øent Treaty ≈øhould be performed in this manner. In witne≈øs whereof we have ≈øigned the ≈øaid pre≈øent Treaty with our Hands, and cau≈øed the Seal of our Arms to be affixed.

closer.signed: Signed, Tallard, Briord, Portland, Jer≈øey, J. van Er≈øen, F. B. de Reede, & Hein≈øius, W. de Na≈ø≈øau, E. de Weede, W. van Haren, Ar‚ñ™ Lemker, van Heek, with their Seals.
